text: <@U85HCL7JP> list comprehensions in languages are map and/or filter [x + 1 for x in xs] # map; [x for x in xs if x > 5] # filter

elements.text: list comprehensions in languages are map and/or filter [x + 1 for x in xs] # map; [x for x in xs if x > 5] # filter

text: In Python there's a special syntax for comprehensions. But that's because higher-order functions are considered exotic for the intended audience. In Lisps, maps and filters and reduces are just ordinary function calls with no special syntax.

elements.text: In Python there's a special syntax for comprehensions. But that's because higher-order functions are considered exotic for the intended audience. In Lisps, maps and filters and reduces are just ordinary function calls with no special syntax.

text:
In listening to the latest podcast a few thoughts.

I'm sure you already know this and I know 100% it's not what you're trying to create but just in case you don't know, Microsoft Word and Microsoft Excel (and I think Microsoft Outlook, and probably Project and PowerPoint) all have Visual Basic built in with an entire giant IDE with form editors, code editors, etc...  I know they aren't running a fancy language, they also are not the actually app code itself but they do let you modify the apps operations and lots of companies use them for custom solutions.

Google Docs/Sheets/etc added JavaScript scripting apparently because Office users were pushing to be able to create similar solutions to the ones they had in MS Products.

There's also things like Photoshop is scriptable from JavaScript and of course a lot of Mac software is scriptable from AppleScript. Windows software is often scriptable from any language that speaks the Windows Scripting Host protocol. That used to include Visual Basic, Perl, Python, JScript and probably includes C# and F# now a days.

Of course on both platforms every app has its own API and is often undocumented. On the Windows one there was a way for each API to expose docs as part of its public interface and there's an API explorer Microsoft provides. It's been so long since I've used it I don't remember what it's called. It might be the OLE object explorer.

That's another tech that I think died out I think. OLE (Object Linking and Embedding) was an Microsoft Standard that let you embed a view of one app inside another. You used to be able to for example select a block of cells in Excel and paste them into Word and have them linked live and if you clicked on the cells in the word document parts of the excel interface would appear. It's been so long since I've used MS Office I have no idea if that's still a thing but they had a standard and 10 to 50 apps supported it. <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_Linking_and_Embedding>

Just passing on info.

I have some thoughts but will let them percolate for a while

attachments.title: Object Linking and Embedding
attachments.text: Object Linking &  Embedding (OLE) is a proprietary technology developed by Microsoft that allows embedding and linking to documents and other objects. For developers, it brought OLE Control Extension (OCX), a way to develop and use custom user interface elements. On a technical level, an OLE object is any object that implements the IOleObject interface, possibly along with a wide range of other interfaces, depending on the object's needs.

text: Interesting context, thanks for sharing <@UC6997THT>! I didn't know all that! Yeah it's both reminiscent what I'm hoping to create and also so far - all these tools and scripting languages off to the side. Of the ones you listed, I've only used Google Sheet's scripting and it was a nightmare. If you compare Google Sheets scripting to <@UBJGA440K>'s Flowsheets, it's really night and day: a system with a FFI for code and a *programming system*

text:
<@U5TCAFTD3> I’m partway through the podcast and it seems like you’re pondering some of the same things I am in terms of content-addressed storage (immutable hashes). For me, it seems like a key part of building programs that wouldn’t break/bitrot over time if the user didn’t want to update. As you mentioned, naming/persistent reference is a problem.

My toy project idea for exploring this space is to figure out how to host a blog on IPFS that contains cycles of links. For the naming thing, one approach is indexing combined with something like Perkeep’s permanodes.

elements.text:
I’m partway through the podcast and it seems like you’re pondering some of the same things I am in terms of content-addressed storage (immutable hashes). For me, it seems like a key part of building programs that wouldn’t break/bitrot over time if the user didn’t want to update. As you mentioned, naming/persistent reference is a problem.

My toy project idea for exploring this space is to figure out how to host a blog on IPFS that contains cycles of links. For the naming thing, one approach is indexing combined with something like Perkeep’s permanodes.

text: I also like the idea of email/productivity apps as the killer app for this system. One of the reasons I use <http://amazingmarvin.com|amazingmarvin.com> as my task manager right now is that it essentially has a gallery of different workflow “strategies” that you can try out on yourself over time. But of course these are all centrally implemented, and I fear for the combinatorial madness that their dev team has to maintain. Something like that where you could build your own workflow strategies would be hard to resist for a lot of hackers.

text: Yeah. That mystifies me. Why does something like Haskell or Erlang need special syntax? I see why a statement oriented language which can be used imperatively (eg. Common Lisp) might want a Loop macro. But in a pure functional language why have special syntax for maps, filter and reduce?

elements.text: Yeah. That mystifies me. Why does something like Haskell or Erlang need special syntax? I see why a statement oriented language which can be used imperatively (eg. Common Lisp) might want a Loop macro. But in a pure functional language why have special syntax for maps, filter and reduce?

text:
Hi Phil - welcome and thanks for posting!

I find the 'network of objects' idea very useful to comprehend or design a system. One thing that comes to mind is whether this network topology is a static or dynamic structure? Also what do you think makes a pattern/assembly different from a class. Presumably you can can construct and pass all the inner objects to the class constructor. In general, I think there are some good ideas here worth exploring.

elements.text:
Hi Phil - welcome and thanks for posting!

I find the 'network of objects' idea very useful to comprehend or design a system. One thing that comes to mind is whether this network topology is a static or dynamic structure? Also what do you think makes a pattern/assembly different from a class. Presumably you can can construct and pass all the inner objects to the class constructor. In general, I think there are some good ideas here worth exploring.
